Afghanistan is classified as a fragile and conflict-affected situations (FCAS) country. The 
coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic has adversely impacted Afghanistan’s economy and 
its  population.  To  mitigate  these  impacts,  the  government  has  adopted  emergency  pro-poor 
countercyclical  measures  and  expenditures  to  strengthen  the  health  system,  expand  social 
protection, and support macroeconomic stabilization and job creation. The proposed program will 
support the government’s COVID-19 countercyclical pandemic response and financing needs to 
help mitigate the adverse health, social, and economic impacts of the crisis, while targeting poor 
and vulnerable groups and ensuring gender mainstreaming.2

ADB Staff Assessment 
As of 23 November 2020, 44,706 COVID-19 cases were reported with 1,687 deaths. The 
economy  has  deteriorated  during  the  pandemic  with  business  lockdowns,  disruptions  in 
supply chains, a downturn in trade and remittances, and a drop in consumer  income and 
demand. The IMF’s 2020 projections indicate (i) a GDP contraction of 5.0% in contrast to a 
GDP  growth  of  3.9%  in  2019,  (ii)  a  widening  of  the  current  account  deficit–GDP  ratio 
(excluding official transfers) to 30.6% from 27.0% in 2019, and (iii) a widening of the budget 
deficit–GDP ratio (excluding grants and loans)  to 21.2% from 13.9% in 2019. The budget 
deficit–GDP ratio (including grants and loans) is projected to increase to 3.0% in 2020 from 
1.1%  in  2019.  Official  reserves  remain  stable  at  $8.9  billion  with  14.3  months  of  import 
coverage in 2020. The afghani–dollar exchange rate has appreciated by 1%, driven by lower 
imports and high currency demand by Afghan nationals in provinces. The national poverty 
rate is projected to reach at least 61.0% (and potentially 72.0%) in 2020 from 54.5% in 2017, 
with an additional 1.9 million–6.0 million people falling into poverty. The unemployment rate 
is projected to rise to 37.9% in 2020 from 23.9% in 2019. 
On 16 March 2020, the government established the High-level Committee for COVID-19 as 
an inter-ministerial taskforce, chaired by the president and the first vice-president, and rolled 
out  its  pro-poor  countercyclical  pandemic  response  package  with  gender  focus  covering 
health-related  measures  aligned  with  the  NERP,  social  protection  measures  and 
macroeconomic  stabilization  measures  (paras.  17−20).  Under  the  instructions  of  this 
committee, the MOF made two amendments to the 2020 national budget approved by the 
president—in  April  2020  and  July  2020—and  a  revision  during  the  midyear  review  in 
September  2020,  approved  by  the  cabinet,  to  reprioritize  resources  for  the  pandemic 
response package of $633.92 million (3.3% of GDP). 
Afghanistan  has  maintained  a  generally  sound  pre-shock  record  of  macroeconomic 
management, anchored to the structural reforms under the IMF’s ECF during 2016−2019. 
Pre-shock GDP growth was 2.6% in 2017, 1.2% in 2018, and 3.9% in 2019. Inflation has 
fallen from 5.0% in 2017 to 0.6% in 2018 and 2.3% in 2019. A broadly balanced fiscal stance

and  debt  sustainability  will  not  be  significantly  affected.  The  public  debt  consisting  of

2020  and  SDR259.04  million  ($370  million)  under  ECF  in  November  2020.  Afghanistan 
received  debt  service  relief  of  SDR4.8  million  ($6.8  million)  in  2020  under  CCRT.  IMF 
provided  its  assessment  report  under  the  ECF,  confirming  sound  macroeconomic

peace negotiations during 2020, have further complicated the fragile health situation.5

6. 
A health emergency of such magnitude has aggravated the pressures on the country’s 
public-sector-led  health  care  system,  providing  mainly  basic  health  care  (with  limited  private 
health care providers), due to large deficiencies in hospital beds, medical personnel, equipment, 
and testing capacity.7 Hospitals also faced challenges to provide health services in areas of active 
conflict. The health care expenditures are primarily borne by high out-of-pocket expenditures of 
the  households  (73%)  because  of  lack  of  health  insurance,  while  the  rest  is  covered  by  the 
government  (6%)  and  international  donors  (21%). 8  With  inadequate  personal  protective 
equipment,  as  of  October  2020,  10%  of  the  COVID-19  infections  were  among  health  care 
professionals, and their subsequent deaths are undermining the response capacity.9 Afghanistan 
ranks 161st out of 195 economies in its capacity to rapidly respond to and mitigate the spread of 
the epidemic, with a score of 23.6 out of 100 based on the Global Health Security Index in 2019.10 
Because there is no national death register, COVID-19 cases and deaths are underreported.11 
Under the scenario of easing community restrictions, daily infections (including those not tested) 
could reach 36,840 by 1 March 2021 with 2,808 deaths, requiring 10,797 hospital beds (2,002 
intensive care unit beds) compared to 5,286 beds (440 intensive care unit beds) available.12

8. 
Economic  impact  of  the  pandemic.  The  government  tightened  the  containment 
measures by placing Kabul and other urban centers under lockdown from late March until early 
August 2020. While the pre-shock macroeconomic management has been sound, the pandemic 
has had a substantial negative economic impact because of the business closures, disruptions in 
supply chains, downturn in trade and remittances, and drop in consumer demand. Based on IMF 
estimates, the economy is projected to contract by 5.0% in 2020 with a downturn in industry and 
services, in contrast to the pre-COVID-19 GDP growth projection of 3.5% for 2020. In 2021, the 
GDP growth is projected to rebound to 4.0%.15 Under a more pessimistic scenario based on World 
Bank estimates,16 incorporating the risks related to the second wave of infection, weather-related 
shocks,  security  challenges,  political  uncertainty,  and  potential  decline  in  international  grants, 
GDP  contraction could  range  between  5.5%  and  7.4%  in  2020  with  only  1.0%  GDP  growth  in 
2021. ADB estimates GDP contraction of 5% in 2020 and 1.5% GDP growth in 2021.17  

 
9.

increase  to  $6.35  billion  (33.3%  of  GDP)  in  2020  driven  by  COVID-19  and  pro-poor-related 
spending,  compared  to  $5.28  billion  (28.0%  of  GDP)  in  2019  and  the  pre-COVID-19  2020 
projection of $5.56 billion (26.6% of GDP). The budget deficit excluding grants and budget support 
loans is projected to increase to $4.04 billion (21.2% of GDP) in 2020, compared to $2.62 billion 
(13.9% of GDP) in 2019 and the pre-COVID-19 2020 projection of $2.85 billion (13.6% of GDP).18

and  civilians  killed  during  conflicts,  and  disabled  veterans  and  civilians  with  special  needs.

employment  and  paying  for  basic  food  and  housing,  which  have  increased  their  debt.  The 
pandemic  has  affected  9  million  school-age  children,  of  which  39%  are  girls.  Around  20%  of

Health impact. Since the first COVID-19 case was reported in Herat on 23 February 2020, the COVID-19 outbreak 
has reached 44,706 confirmed cases with 1,617 deaths as of 23 November 2020 based on WHO data. A public health 
emergency  caused  by  the  pandemic  has  aggravated  the  pressures  on  the  constrained  health  care  system 
infrastructure  and  capacity  due  to  large  deficiencies  in  hospital  beds,  medical  equipment,  personnel,  and  testing 
capacity. The fragile health situation in Afghanistan is further complicated by the ongoing armed conflict, insecurity 
and political uncertainties, influx of 666,257 Afghan migrants and refugees from Iran and 5,502 from Pakistan during 
January–October 2020, and more than 86,419 IDPs by the end of May 2020 due to conflict and disasters triggered by 
natural hazards. Due to limited public health resources and testing capacity, reluctance of people coming forward for 
testing due to social stigma on COVID-19, as well as the absence of a national death register, confirmed cases of and 
deaths from COVID-19 are likely to be underreported across Afghanistan. The WHO notes that the official numbers 
are unlikely to be capturing the full scale of the situation since testing remains limited to only the most severe cases. 
 
Besides the challenges faced by hospitals to treat patients with COVID-19 and maintain health services, especially in 
areas of active conflict, the COVID-19 pandemic has put additional financial burden on the citizens, infected with the 
virus. While the MOPH provides a basic package of health services (introduced in 2003) and an essential package of 
hospital services (introduced in 2005) together with the nongovernmental organizations, which  are free for Afghan 
citizens, in the absence of comprehensive health insurance, the cost of the health care expenditures is primarily borne 
by high out-of-pocket expenditures of the households (73%) while the rest is covered by the government (6%) and 
international donors (21%). The World Bank, the European Union, and the USAID are the three largest donors to both 
packages. With support from the USAID, the MOPH had earlier developed a document for health financing policy for 
2012−2020 and a strategy. However, absence of a legal framework for state-funded insurance schemes, gaps in the 
taxation system and lack of risk pooling mechanisms for households have impeded the health insurance development. 
 
Economic impact. Because of the lockdown measures since late March 2020 impacting local businesses, disruptions 
in supply chains, regional trade, and a drop in consumer demand with income shock borne by the households, the 
pandemic has led to a sharp contraction in the economy. Based on the IMF estimates, in contrast to the pre-COVID-
19 GDP growth projection of 3.5% for 2020, the economy is projected to contract by 5.0% in 2020 from a growth of 
3.9%  in  2019.  A  growth  of  5%  in  agriculture  sector  due  to  favorable  weather  conditions  is  offset  by  the  projected 
contraction in industry by 5% and in services by 9.6% in 2020.  
 
Fiscal  pressure.  The  pandemic  is  creating  significant  fiscal  pressure  on  Afghanistan.  Based  on  IMF  estimates, 
domestic revenues are projected to decline to $2.31 billion (12.1% of GDP) in 2020 compared to $2.66 billion (14.1%

to increase to $6.35 billion (33.3% of GDP) in 2020 driven by COVID-19 and pro-poor related spending compared to 
$5.28 billion (28.0% of GDP) in 2019 and the pre-COVID-19 2020 projection of $5.56 billion (26.6% of GDP).

Afghanistan achieved GDP growth of 2.6% in 2017, 1.2% in 2018 and 3.9% in 2019 driven by the agriculture sector’s

financial supervisory framework by establishing the Financial Stability Committee. To strengthen the financial inclusion 
and financial sector intermediation,  the  government has started  implementation  of the National Financial Inclusion 
Strategy, 2019–2024 since September 2019.  
 
With continued aid inflows (reaching nearly 40% of GDP), the government has maintained a broadly balanced fiscal 
stance with budget deficit (including grants and loans)−GDP ratios of 0.7% in 2017 and 1.1% in 2019 while having a 
surplus of 1.6% in 2018. Reflecting improvements in budget execution and prioritization, operating expenditures−GDP 
ratio has declined from 19.7% of GDP in 2017 to 18.5% in 2019, while the development expenditures−GDP ratio has 
increased from 8.0% in 2017 to 9.5% in 2019 and pro-poor spending−GDP ratio has increased from 3.0% in 2017 to

2017−2019) have accounted for 14.5 months of imports in 2019 and public debt−GDP ratio has remained stable at 
about 6% under a policy of highly concessional external borrowing. Domestic borrowing is negligible in Afghanistan 
with only two promissory note issuances worth 1.2% of GDP in 2017 and 0.5% of GDP in 2018 but the issuances 
were discontinued in 2019 and 2020.  
 
Large current account deficits have continued to be financed by donor grants. The current account surplus including 
official transfers has increased from 7.6% in 2017 to 12.2% in 2018 and 11.7% in 2019. To reduce aid dependence,

approved  in  November  2020.  The  government  remains  committed  to  implementation  of  macroeconomic  structural

Institutional framework of health sector measures. The MOPH approved the NERP for COVID-19 in March 2020 
and developed an action plan for the preventive measures. A new structure within MOPH was created to implement 
the  NERP  and  the  action  plan.  The  NERP  details  the  medium  and  long-term  strategy  for  a  robust  national  health 
security agenda for all hazards and pandemic preparedness, as well as the resource requirements and development 
coordination  for  (i)  surveillance  and  detection;  (ii)  early  diagnosis,  isolation,  and  case  management;  (iii)  infection 
prevention and control in health facilities and communities; (iv) risk mitigation; and (v) resource allocation for logistics 
and procurement for emergency responses based on the COVID-19 preparedness and response plans of the WHO 
and  the  UNICEF.  Based  on  NERP,  the  estimated  health  sector  resource  requirement  for  the  pandemic  response 
(using three scenarios of low to high transmission) ranges between $123 million to $892 million.  
 
In April 2020, provincial emergency committees for COVID-19 were formed in all 34 provinces, comprising governors, 
provincial councils, provincial health administrations, municipalities, and civil society in collaboration with WHO and 
relevant UN agencies for surveillance, health care services, and risk communication. The local governments play a 
critical  role  in  implementation  of  national  containment  measures  as  well  as  provision  of  vital  services  and  social 
protection support. 
 
Implementation of health sector measures. Based on the national action plan, the MOPH has been strengthening 
the capacity of medical facilities with strong gender focus such as establishment of women-only treatment areas at 
identified  medical  facilities  and  provision  of  appropriately  sized  personal  protective  gears,  including  individual 
packages for female health workers. Nearly 570,000 units of personal protective equipment were provided to health 
workers nationwide as of 12 November 2020 with support from development partners such as WHO, World Bank, 
UNICEF  and  bilateral  donors.  Furthermore,  8  hospitals  have  been  designated  for  exclusive  use  by  the  COVID-19 
patients; around 3,100 beds in 34 provinces have  been  assigned  to  COVID-19  patients, from which  1,030 are for 
critical patients. Medical equipment has been provided for 1,642 isolation beds across all 34 provinces. A new 100-
bed COVID-19 hospital has been opened in Herat province. In Kabul, the Darulaman Palace (300 beds) as well as 
Kabul and Polytechnic universities’ dormitories have been converted to isolation facilities. MOPH has been preparing

have been providing support to MOPH to rehabilitate and expand new treatment facilities including prefabricated ones. 
 
A  total  of  14  COVID-19  testing  labs  across  the  country  with  5  labs  in  Kabul  were  established,  equipped  with  500 
ventilators purchased through the National Procurement Authority, polymerase chain reaction machines and testing 
kits. As of 12 November 2020, 4,350 healthcare workers received training on infection prevention and control, 3,931 
healthcare  workers  on  surveillance  and  risk  communication,  444  healthcare  workers  on  intensive  care  and  193 
healthcare workers on medical laboratory testing. With the private hospitals also allowed to conduct tests, Afghanistan 
has reached the capacity to carry out 5,500 tests per day and as of 19 November 2020, 133,691 tests were conducted.  
 
To strengthen surveillance and early detection, in addition to 525 MOPH sites, COVID-19 surveillance sites in airports, 
borders, and city entrance points have been established and mobile teams have been trained.  As of 12 November 
2020,  519,023  people  have  been  medically  screened  at  points-of-entry  and  the  surveillance  systems  have  traced 
591,232 people since the start of the crisis in March 2020.  Nearly 4,000 governmental and nongovernmental units 
operate  across  the  country  to  gather  information  daily  and  share  with  the  national  and  international  health 
organizations.  MOPH  has  recruited  and  trained  more  than  6,000  medical  staff  with  additional  3,000  medical  staff 
planned to be hired. Medical staff has been provided salaries with incentive payments. 
 
A  nationwide  gender-sensitive  public  awareness  campaign  on  COVID-19  has  been  carried  out  by  the  MOPH  and 
Ministry of Women Affairs. Using mosques, educational institutions as well as national print and broadcasting media, 
social media, billboards, cell phone messages, around 10 million pieces of COVID-19 related informational documents 
have been distributed. Nearly 3 million people have been sensitized about hygiene promotion through handwashing 
stations and distribution of hygiene kits. Ministry of Women Affairs has been involved in 117 districts in 26 provinces 
by (i) visiting women jails, safe homes, shelters, businesses headed by women, orphanages, private banks, hospitals 
and clinics to distribute gender-sensitive information and sanitary kits, (ii) monitoring adherence to safety measures, 
and  (iii)  facilitating  gender-sensitive  services  for  women,  particularly  in  hospitals  with  all  women-only  treatment 
facilities. Health kits for street children have been distributed. A call center was set up at MOPH.  
 
Development partner support. The government has also received support from the WHO, United Nations agencies, 
and development partners for procurement of medical equipment and supplies, expansion of health sector capacity 
with new facilities,  capacity building on pandemic management and provision of  health services for the vulnerable 
communities such as IDPs, refugees, women and children during the pandemic. Besides the health sector measures, 
the  government’s  response  includes  expansion  of  social  protection  for  the  poor  and  vulnerable  people,  and 
macroeconomic stabilization measures with further details provided under criteria 2.  
 
Afghanistan has become eligible for DSSI, endorsed in April 2020 by the World Bank’s Development Committee and 
the G20 finance ministers in response to a call by the World Bank and the IMF to grant debt service suspension to the 
poorest  countries.  In  return,  beneficiaries  of  DSSI  commit  to  use  freed-up  resources  to  increase  social,  health,  or 
economic spending in response to the pandemic while disclosing all public sector financial commitments (involving

programs  and  the  World  Bank’s  non-concessional  borrowing  policies.  Around  $4  million  of  interest  and  principal 
payments to bilateral creditors during May−December 2020 will be paid starting 2022. Afghanistan’s potential DSSI 
savings are $39.1 million (0.2% of 2019 GDP) based on estimated debt service payments. Furthermore, the IMF has 
provided debt service relief of SDR4.8 million ($6.8 million) under two tranches in April 2020 and October 2020 with 
a total relief of SDR10.05 million ($14.4 million) by 2022 under the Catastrophe Containment and Relief Trust. 
 
During the pandemic, the IMF provided a concessional loan of SDR161.9 million ($220 million) under the Rapid Credit 
Facility, approved on 29 April 2020. An additional concessional IMF loan of SDR259.04 million ($370 million) under 
the ECF arrangement was approved on 6 November 2020. These budget support loans represent 49% of outstanding 
public debt stock of $1.2 billion. In 2020, Afghanistan also received infrastructure project loans of $208 million from 
some development partners adding another 17% to the public debt stock. Based on ADB’s DSA, which simulated 
scenarios on drivers of debt dynamics such as growth, exchange rate, real interest rate, and primary deficit, these 
loans will increase the public debt−GDP ratio from 6.3% in 2019 to 10.7% in 2020 and 16.6% of GDP in 2021, however 
the ratio is projected to decline to 13.4% in 2024. These loans will not significantly increase the annual debt service 
obligations and debt sustainability as the  public debt  will stay moderately low.  ADB’s $100  million grant  under the 
CARES Program will help create fiscal space and improve debt sustainability during the pandemic.  
 
Afghanistan’s public debt sustainability hinges on continuing net inflows of highly concessional development finance 
over the medium and long term. Liabilities consist mostly of concessional and project-based loans from multilateral 
and bilateral creditors. This keeps borrowing costs low and limits rollover and interest-rate risks, although the foreign-
currency denomination of public external debt constitutes currency risk.  
 
Nevertheless, the IMF’s pre-shock DSA under Article IV consultation report in 2019 and its DSA after the pandemic 
in Rapid Credit Facility report in April 2020 and in ECF report in November 2020 as well as ADB’s recent DSA rate 
Afghanistan at high risk of debt distress mainly because of an expected decline of grants financing fiscal and external 
deficits in the medium and long term. Key factors for the high risk of debt distress are (i) high dependence on donor 
grant inflows, which finance substantial fiscal and external  deficits, (ii) the expected replacement of  grants by debt 
financing  over  time,  which  will  increase  the  debt  service  burden  given  the  weak  debt  carrying  and  low  revenue 
generation capacities, (iii) export shocks, and (iv) the fragile political and security situation.  
 
To facilitate transitioning of the low-income countries (including Afghanistan) to non-concessional borrowing, the IMF 
and World Bank have approved the SDFP in effect from 1 July 2020 to strengthen public debt management framework. 
This is aligned with the IMF and the World Bank support for the implementation of the DSSI—by monitoring spending, 
enhancing public debt transparency, and ensuring prudent borrowing. ADB will continue to support debt sustainability 
during the Asian Development Fund 13 period (2021−2024) through additional TA for its developing member countries 
for the implementation the SDFP.
